(Soundbite of digging)
Burras is driving a spade into the soil.
Cutting through the web of roots, he pulls up a big clump.
So now we have a piece of Iowa soil - beautiful prairie-derived soil.
And you look at that as a soil scientist, what do you see?
Well, the first thing I'm noticing is how black it is - beautifully black.
Black like coal, like oil, like charcoal, because this soil is also full of carbon - organic carbon, or humus, Burras calls it.
What's left from countless generations of rotting plants.
But now that we've exposed the soil to sun and oxygen, we've started to destroy that legacy.
Microbes in the soil are going to work on the humus, eating it and breathing out carbon dioxide, as if they were burning up the soil.
This is what happens when farmers till the land.
The tearing of the soil, introducing more oxygen - that's what tillage is all about.
And the history of human civilization is tillage.
I believe it was Daniel Webster who said where tillage begins, other arts follow.
But tillage also changes the Earth.
Burras walks a hundred feet to the east into a field planted with soybeans.
Here, once again, he turns over some soil.
One of the most striking differences, as we look at this, is the field is a little grayer.
It's not quite as black.
And that reflects the past century of plowing and such.
We've seen the organic carbon content of this field go from maybe five percent organic carbon down to three percent organic carbon.
That means every acre of this field has vented about 50 tons of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere.
It's about as much as eight cars pump out in a year.
And there are billions of acres of farmland around the globe.
Rattan Lal, a soil scientist at Ohio State University, has traveled the world studying those fields, trying to calculate how much carbon farmers have unleashed.
From time immemorial when the world agriculture began, we have lost roughly 140 billion tons of carbon from trees and soil.
In fact, until the 1950s, plowing had released more carbon dioxide into the air than all the burning of coal and oil.
Now this would be just ancient history, except for one thing: a coal mine can't magically suck some of its carbon back into the Earth.
The soil, though, can if you treat it right.
You could call it farming carbon.
(Soundbite of machinery)
This Iowa farmer is planting soybeans without plowing up the soil.
Sharp steel wheels cut through last year's corn stalks, opening up a narrow slit in the soil.
Seeds drop through a tube into the opening, then a wheel comes along and closes it up again.
It's called no-till planting because it doesn't stir up the soil.
It lets the land keep its stored carbon and even adds some, because those corn stalks on the surface gradually become part of the soil.
In fact by some calculations, each acre of no-till land in Iowa captures about a ton of carbon dioxide from the air each year.
At that rate, a seven-acre cornfield inhales about as much of this greenhouse gas as the average American car exhales.
But no-till isn't the only way to grow a carbon crop.
So this is finished compost over here that is ready to go on to our fields.
You can see that it looks like rich soil.
Paul Hepperly is in charge of research at the Rodale Institute in Kutztown, Pennsylvania.
It's a showcase of organic farming methods.
There's very little sign of what this compost used to be - tree leaves and cow manure.
It smells just like good rich soil.
Compost is one reason why the fields of the Rodale Institute have been getting richer in carbon year after year.
In Searsboro, Iowa, meanwhile, Russell Hughes stopped growing corn or soybeans on part of his farm and turned it into pasture for cattle.
Grass and clover covers this ground year-round; the roots grow deep.
In a small respect, you're going back to, you know, closer to what the prairie was doing when it was here.
I mean, you know, as long as you have roots down there that are holding the soil, you know, you're adding a little all the time.
And if everybody did such things it could add a lot.

According to Rattan Lal, from Ohio State, American soil could - at least in theory - capture more than a hundred million tons of carbon a year, enough to offset the emissions from half the cars in the country.
If we want to kick the carbon habit, as our president has asked, agriculture is an important part of the solution to rehabilitating our carbon civilization.
Lal says the real beauty of this is no-till farming or growing more grass and hay costs very little.
Also farming this way helps the environment in lots of ways; the land becomes more of a sponge for water, less soil and fertilizer washes into nearby streams.
It's a truly win, win, win.
Oversee and verse.
In a small way, though, carbon farming has begun.
Under a program run by the Iowa Farm Bureau, almost 2,000 farmers are getting paid a few dollars for every acre of their no-till land or pasture.
The money comes from businesses that are trying to balance their greenhouse gas emissions.
Right now, those businesses aren't paying a lot, but that could change, if Congress passes strict limits on greenhouse gas emissions.
Then, farmers might actually earn some real money capturing carbon.
Dan Charles, NPR News.

In Paris today, yet another demonstration against a youth labor law, and another round of violence afterwards.

Students, union workers, and other supporters have rallied in Paris and other cities around France over the past couple of weeks to protest the new labor law that's due to take effect at the end of the April.
The measure would allow companies to fire workers under the age of 26 without giving any reason during their first two years on the job.
France has one of the highest unemployment rates among people under the age of 25, close to 23 present.
Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin, who introduced this legislation, says he intended this to help young people find work.
(Through translator) We are faced with a precarious situation of high youth unemployment which is only getting worse.
I want France to try and advance.
So I ask the French people to be pragmatic, to try new solutions, and to move forward.
As the protests gather force, Prime Minister de Villepin is under increasing pressure to withdraw his law.
Joining us now on the phone from Paris is Peter Ford, Chief European Correspondent for the Christian Science Monitor.
Peter, nice to have you back on the program.
Yeah, I'm glad to be here.
Reacting, it seems to pressure, Mr. de Villepin invited the leaders of the major unions to meet with him tomorrow to discuss the labor laws.
Is this a breakthrough?

Well, it may be the beginning of a breakthrough, but the unions decided today to accept the invitation to go and see Mr. de Villepin, but what they're going to tell him is that before they're going to discuss anything, they want him to withdraw the law.
Now whether he'll do that or not we'll have to see.
So it's only the start.
And it could be a short meeting in that respect.
It could indeed.
On the other hand, I think that neither side in this really wants to take the battle to a major final confrontation.
I think there is a will on both sides to try and pull back from the brink on this.
Mr.
de Villepin has to address a situation where there are, I think almost universal complaints about the French labor system, which is very inflexible.
Yes.
It, once you've got an open-ended contract, and about 85 present of French workers have open-ended contracts, it's not easy to be fired.
And employers say that they're only going to start hiring people in greater numbers, and thus bring down unemployment, if they are allowed to get rid of workers when they need to.
If economic factors (unintelligible) they have to lay off some of their workforce.
That was the plan behind this new labor contract.
It would make it easier to fire, so they thought it would make it easier to hire.
But that undermines a very strong and deep tradition in France of job security, and young people do not want to be made the victims of the labor crisis.
And to some degree, this new labor law was a response to the last round of youth violence in France.
That in the suburbs outside of Paris, where Muslim youths were saying we can't get jobs at all.
Yes, the sorts of people who are demonstrating in Paris at the moment are very, very different.
These are mostly university students and high school kids who come from relatively well-off parents.
But they're worried about, though, in the same sense of the young people in the poor suburbs, is whether or not French society has room for them; whether they can make a place for them.

With 25 percent, nearly 25 percent unemployment amongst young people under the age of 26, it's increasingly clear to them, to young people, that French society is immobile and cannot find room for them to play their full role.
We're talking with Peter Ford, chief European correspondent for the Christian Science Monitor.
